div.p: THE SENTIMENTS of N. N. (A loyal Subject of the Roman Catholick Communion) Touching the ROMAN CONSISTORIE'S De≈øigns and Practices, By and with their Corre≈øpondents here, (Viz. the Je≈øuits, Monks and Friers) to the Prejudice of this NATION, and the future involving it in mi≈øery and trouble, under the (feigned) pretence of advanceing Catholick Religion;

TOGETHER With ≈øome General Remedies or Expedients, for preventing thereof: EXPRESSED In certain PROPOSITIONS, and humbly Submitted to the Cen≈øure of Tho≈øe, who≈øe Prudence, or Authority inables them better to judge of Things.
LONDON, Printed for HENRY BROME, at the Gun in St. Paul's Church-Yard, MDCLXXIX.

q.p:
BE pleas'd (good Reader) to take notice, that in pur≈øuance of ≈øome Verbal Di≈øcour≈øe had with two Reverend Per≈øons of the Church of England, ≈øome Years ≈øince decea≈øed, Mr. Thorndike. Mr. Thre≈ø≈øcro≈øs. the following matters were fir≈øt committed to Paper, in, or about the Year 1668. at which time it was much fear'd, and talk'd by many, as if ≈øome mi≈øunder≈øtanding would have happened betwixt the King and Parliament upon occa≈øion of the then late Dreadful Burning of the City: and the Writers intention was, ≈øo far as it lay in the power of ≈øuch a private Subject, to endeavour, by giving a timely Warning to all Per≈øons concern'd, to prevent (if po≈ø≈øible) ≈øo great inconveniences, and mi≈øchiefs, as would undoubtedly have followed ≈øuch a Breach: in order to which prevention, he was al≈øo willing for his part, that his Sentiments ≈øhould have been made publick, at the time when he first declar'd them. But that Cloud by the good Providence of God, and the wi≈øe proceeding of Parliament, ≈øcattering as it were of it ≈øelf, and Serenity of State returning, Tho≈øe Reverend Per≈øons above named (who≈øe further encouragement and a≈ø≈øi≈øtance (to ≈øpeak the truth) was of nece≈ø≈øity to have been afforded to the Publication of them) judg'd it not fit to hinder the quiet compo≈øure of things, by ca≈øting in ought that might move di≈øpute, mini≈øter talk, or ≈øerve to keep on foot publick jealou≈øies, and di≈øcontents. So they have lain ever ≈øince in the ≈øame private Manu≈øcript, in which they were fir≈øt drawn up. But (as it happens by the ≈øame Permi≈ø≈øion, and order of Divine Providence)
the face of publick affairs beginning now again to change ≈øo much to the wor≈øe, and the pre≈øent state of things ≈øo evidently confirming, and fully ju≈øtifying tho≈øe General fears, ≈øu≈øpicions, and jealou≈øies, which the Writer of the≈øe following Propo≈øitions profe≈ø≈øes to have had, and to have laboured under a long time together; to the end, that our great, and high-contra≈øting Animo≈øities do not hurry us unawares, into irremediable Evils, the Author hath now a ≈øecond time given his con≈øent to their Publication, in the ≈øame form and manner, and without any great alteration from what they were in the fir≈øt Copy: Verily judging the Contents, if well and duly con≈øider'd, may, with God's ble≈ø≈øing going along with them; ≈øerve in this juncture of time as ≈øo many ≈øea≈øonable Retentives, to hold us back from running ≈øo ha≈øtily and headlong to our own ruine; or as ≈øo many gentle ≈øuffu≈øions to correct, and cool the vehemency of our di≈øtempered heats.

It is therefore, both by the Author and Publi≈øher, heartily wi≈øh'd and de≈øir'd, that his private Thoughts, hereby made publick, might be ≈øo happy, as to come to the knowledge, and be thoroughly reflected upon by all the good People of this Nation: and particularly, I cannot but prompt to them tho≈øe Propo≈øitions which concern, and ≈øhew the means of Cementing our Unhappy differences, and thereby fru≈øtrating the hopes and De≈øigns our Enemies have upon us, by rea≈øon of them; which are Propp. 24, 25, 26, 27, 28, 29, 30, 31, 32. Tho≈øe al≈øo that di≈øcover, and lay open the various, and ≈øubtle practices of our great Enemy (the Roman Con≈øi≈øtory and its Emi≈ø≈øaries) to kindle, and keep up Di≈ø≈øen≈øions amongst us, and by means of them in fine to ≈øubject us, not ≈øo much to the obedience of True Religion (which they neither regard, nor care for, but only for their Intere≈øts ≈øake) as to their own arbitrary Wills, Pride, Tyranny, and Super≈øtitions: Which likewi≈øe, if God permit, and that moderate Coun≈øels take not better place with us, they will infallibly effect fir≈øt or la≈øt. Nothing can hinder, or prevent them, but our own timely Uniting, and joyning together hearts and hands, Coun≈øels
and Intere≈øts, Affections, Endeavours, and All what≈øoever we have, or can make u≈øe of for common defence, in ≈øuch manner as is hinted in the above-mention'd Propp. 24, 25, 26, &c. But for their practices, ≈øee Propp. 7, 8, 9, 10, 11, 12, 13, 14, 17, 18, 19, 20, 23. And finally, that we do not omit to con≈øider what is ≈øaid concerning the Je≈øuits immen≈øe Wealth, mo≈øt unlawfully gotten, and rak'd together, and of its perilous importance to all Princes, and States what≈øoever, where they have the like advantages, and do practi≈øe the like indu≈øtries for the ama≈ø≈øing wealth in a clande≈øtine, and le≈øs perceived way. Neither do the Monks (or other Religious, I ≈øuppo≈øe) fall much ≈øhort of their proportion in each kind, that is, of having, and po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øing exce≈ø≈øively-≈øuperfluous Mammon, or Riches, and of avaritious indu≈øtry, diligence, and de≈øire to get more. For this, as relating to the Je≈øuits e≈øpecially, ≈øee Propp. 33, 34, 35, 36, 37, 38, 39, 41. And for the Intere≈øt and Power, the Con≈øi≈øtory, and they, Viz. the Je≈øuits, Monks, and Friers, have al≈øo now gained, and do at pre≈øent hold, and drive on out of Chri≈øtendom, that is, in the Turki≈øh, Per≈øian, and Chine≈øe Empires, ≈øee Propp. 48. to the end of the Di≈øcour≈øe.

Now concerning the Author, or Writer of the following matters, there needs no more be inquir'd, or ≈øaid of him, than what him≈øelf confe≈ø≈øeth in the Title-page, viz. that he is, as to matter of Faith and Religion, of the Roman-Catholick Communion; but yet a Loyal Subject, and one that hates all kind of di≈øloyalty (whether in opinion or practice) as much as any Prote≈øtant in England: of which he is al≈øo ready at all times (when requir'd) to give the best a≈ø≈øurance he can, and the utmo≈øt that the Law requires of the Subjects of this Nation: being indeed one, who≈øe private condition con≈øidered, cannot ea≈øily be thought to have any de≈øign in publi≈øhing the≈øe his Sentiments, more than to be (under God) ≈øome little means of helping to prevent the manifold Confu≈øions, troubles, mi≈øeries, deva≈øtations and bloud-≈øhed, which tho≈øe hasty and precipitate Coun≈øels, that ≈øome are found too ready to advance, partly out of a mi≈øtaken zeal for Religion, (which is in
truth meer animo≈øity and haughtine≈øs of ≈øpirit) and partly for their own private ends, will certainly in ≈øhort time bring upon his native Country, far more grievous, than any they have yet felt, or ≈øeen in War. And therefore prayeth, that his good and dutiful Intentions being accepted, his over≈øights (in ca≈øe any ≈øuch be found to have ≈ølipt his Pen, worthy of remarque) may receive a mild cen≈øure, and be look'd upon as the Effects (for ≈øo they are, I appeal to God) of a mo≈øt pure, and inten≈øe affection for the good of this Nation in general; and in particular for the Health and Well-being of his Maje≈øties Royal Per≈øon, for his ≈øafety and pre≈øervation from all dangers, publick or private, and for his long, happy, and peaceful Reign over us: likewi≈øe (as duty requires) for the health and happy return (when it ≈øhall be ≈øafe for him) of his Royal Highne≈øs: and in the mean time for the inviolate Con≈øervation of all his Princely Rights, Titles, Dignities, and Prerogatives to him and his Heirs; and for the fru≈øtrating of all tho≈øe de≈øperate and de≈øtructive Coun≈øels and Practices, which are ≈øaid to be carried on for the di≈øinheriting of his Royal Highne≈øs becau≈øe of his Religion: than which de≈øign, nothing ever was, or can be thought of, more Unadvi≈øed, and tending to the Nations ruine; or that doth more evidently proclaim it ≈øelf to be the very coun≈øel, and project of tho≈øe our deadly enemies here complain'd of: who have by ≈øome of their hired, or brib'd Agents among≈øt us, clancularly and underhand procur'd it to be ≈øet on foot, on purpo≈øe to involve us in endle≈øs and inextricable troubles, contentions and mi≈øchiefs following upon them; from which God in mercy deliver Us, and cau≈øe us to ≈øee (I ≈øay not only the iniquity, inju≈øtice, illegalne≈øs of the Project, which are apparent to every eye, but) the manife≈øt impo≈ø≈øibility of ever carrying it on, and maintaining it again≈øt ≈øo many and great oppo≈øitions (both dome≈øtick and foreign) as will undoubtedly appear again≈øt it, when the re≈øolution ≈øhall be once taken, and form'd into an Act of State: Which that it may never be, nor the traiterous phan≈øie ever be thought worthy of motion, but rather be look'd upon with
horrour, and rejected with de≈øerv'd indignation by all the good Members of our en≈øuing Great Council, the Parliament, as al≈øo by all Good Patriots, Lovers and Well-wi≈øhers of their Countries publick, and common Good, Peace, Tranquillity, Quiet, more than their own Wills, private Pa≈ø≈øions, Intere≈øts, and Concerns, is, and ever ≈øhall be (as both Duty and Con≈øcience binds) the daily, and mo≈øt earne≈øt Prayer, of (Good Reader) Your loving Country-man, and mo≈øt hearty Well-wi≈øher of the Be≈øt Things to You from God.

div.head: TO THE REVEREND, His mo≈øt Honoured good FRIENDS, Mr. H. Th. and Mr. N. Thr. Divines, and Dignitaries of the Church of England.

opener.salute: Reverend, and my much Honoured good Friends,

div.p:
COncerning the bu≈øine≈øs, whereof I lately promi≈øed to give You ≈øome account by Writing, being a little ≈øtraitned in point of Time, I mu≈øt crave Your pardon, if you find not that good method and order ob≈øerv'd in the following Lines, which might have been wi≈øhed, and that I pre≈øume to deliver my Thoughts to You in ≈øuch an indige≈øted manner, as I fear I ≈øhall be forc'd to do for want of time, that is to ≈øay, not in the form of a continued, and coherent Di≈øcour≈øe, but of di≈øtinct, ≈øeparate Propo≈øitions, ≈øet down ha≈øtily, as Things come to mind. However, I think this Benefit may come of the cour≈øe I intend, that delivering my ≈øelf in this manner, you will, perhaps, ≈øomewhat more di≈øtinctly, and particularly perceive what my mind is, and what ≈øen≈øe and apprehen≈øion of things I have: which I confe≈øs is the principal thing I aim at; as well to ea≈øe my own mind, as to under≈øtand what yours will be of the whole matter. I can hardly doubt, but in ≈øome things you will think me a little too apprehen≈øive, and that I do over≈øhoot my ≈øelf in ≈øu≈øpicion. But for that (Gentlemen) appealing to God for the ≈øincerity of my profe≈ø≈øion herein, I think it ≈øufficient to ≈øay, it is a ca≈øe, wherein I had much rather be blam'd for want of Di≈øcretion, than for want of Affection: and ≈øo I may be, though in never ≈øo low a degree, an
occa≈øion, or means, of preventing the ≈øad mi≈øchief and trouble, which I verily believe threatens this Church and Kingdom, from the practices of certain Men, who pretend Religion much, but mind it lea≈øt of all, I ≈øhall not be unwilling to be accounted a Fool, or Mad-man, if need be.

As I have already told you, I can frame no particular accu≈øation again≈øt any Per≈øon; but mu≈øt confe≈øs, my Fears and apprehen≈øions are only of dangers and ill practices in general, and for the mo≈øt part upon general pre≈øumptions and grounds: ≈øo that I cannot but doubt likewi≈øe, that this will be objected again≈øt me, and made a great argument by ≈øome to di≈øcredit what I ≈øay, Viz. that I do only ≈øu≈øpect, and not prove. But let them make their advantage of it. I am content to lye under this cen≈øure too for a while, rather than that my Country ≈øhould want the benefit of ≈øome timely admonition, and warning given them, to beware, how they ≈øuffer them≈øelves to be practis'd upon, to their own and the publick ruine. Dangers of this nature mu≈øt be fear'd, and apprehended, a little before they evidence them≈øelves, or el≈øe God help us. For the ≈øati≈øfaction (I hope) of all that will judge indifferently, it may ≈øuffice, that with a clear con≈øcience I can, and do appeal to God, the ≈øearcher of hearts, that I ≈øugge≈øt nothing, either by way of charge, ≈øu≈øpicion, accu≈øation, or otherwi≈øe, which I do not verily conceive my ≈øelf to have ju≈øt and ≈øufficient ground to ≈øugge≈øt, and to think, and ≈øpeak of Things ≈øo as I do, either from their own printed Books, or from their private Writings (which I have at times ≈øeen, and tran≈øcribed for them) or from what I have heard from their own mouths, or the mouths of their friends and confidents: except only ≈øome few things, which here and there I collect, √† paritate rationis, or by way of argument, from what I have undoubtedly heard, or ob≈øerv'd from them≈øelves, and from their Books, Writings, Mouths, re≈øpectively.

All that know, and duly con≈øider how indu≈øtrious this Party is, to pur≈øue and promote their proper Intere≈øt, will (I doubt not) acknowledge this for a truth, That what they hold
lawful to be done, they may be ju≈øtly pre≈øum'd to do, when≈øoever opportunity ≈øerves, and that they ≈øee it conducible to their Intere≈øt to do it. Therefore to ≈øhew how they are principled in point of opinion, touching the lawfulne≈øs of the things here in general charg'd upon them, or ≈øu≈øpected of them, I ≈øhall not forget, in convenient place, to in≈øert ≈øome few of their Maximes, ≈øerving to that purpo≈øe.

One thing I have yet farther to add, not in the quality of a rea≈øon, to move others to regard what I ≈øay, (though it be, I confe≈øs, ≈øome little occa≈øion of ≈øatisfaction to my ≈øelf) but only becau≈øe I judge it not improper to be imparted to you (my Honoured Friends) and that I am particularly de≈øirous to hear your opinion of it. It is this: That being my ≈øelf a Roman Catholick, and frequenting the Sacrament of Confe≈ø≈øion, as Catholicks u≈øe to do, I have had frequent occa≈øion to mention the≈øe following matters, at lea≈øt the general Heads of them, to my (then) Gho≈øtly Fathers, as things that carried a ≈øemblance with them of very ra≈øh judgments again≈øt ≈øo great Superiours, and again≈øt Religious men, and upon that account as being matter of ≈øin, or ju≈øt ≈øcruple, to me. But neither could I ever hear any thing from them, that gave me the lea≈øt ≈øatisfactory a≈ø≈øurance of the contrary, Viz. That it was not in any ≈øort ≈øo as I fear'd and ≈øu≈øpected of them, (though they were Je≈øuits, for the mo≈øt part, to whom I made my confe≈ø≈øion, and ≈øuch Men as could ea≈øily have given me a≈ø≈øurance, had they known it to be otherwi≈øe than I ≈øu≈øpected:) neither could I ever find any Benefit by confe≈ø≈øing them. But though I have ever made it my earne≈øt Prayer to God, and ≈øtill do every day, that he would give me the grace to judge rightly and ju≈øtly of all Men, and not to be tran≈øported with any judgments, or ≈øu≈øpicions concerning others, contrary to Truth and Charity: Yet the≈øe ≈øtill continue, and rather grow, and encrea≈øe upon me, than otherwi≈øe, di≈øquieting my mind, more or le≈øs, almo≈øt every day; being commonly the la≈øt things that leave me at Night, and returning with the fir≈øt in the Morning. And this hath been
my condition the≈øe many Years: Which ≈øeeing that my con≈øcience, on the other ≈øide, clears me from bearing any grudge, or offence of mind (upon my own, or any other Man's account) towards any Per≈øon, or Per≈øons living; and that even in relation to tho≈øe, whom in the general I cannot but think and ≈øu≈øpect to be very faulty, I find not my ≈øelf otherwi≈øe affected, than mo≈øt truly to love, honour, and re≈øpect them for their Calling and Characters ≈øake. I cannot but for this rea≈øon al≈øo a little the more yield to my own fears, and think, that in fearing and judging ≈øo as I do, my fear is not altogether without cau≈øe, nor my judgment much contrary to Truth and Charity. However, ≈øuch as they are, in order to receive your further Coun≈øel and Direction concerning them, I take the Boldne≈øs to pre≈øent them to You, in the plain Form that followeth.

div.head: The SENTIMENTS of N. N. Touching the ROMAN Con≈øi≈øtories, DESIGNS and PRACTICES, &c.
The Fir≈øt Propo≈øition.
div.p: THat though the Roman Catholick Religion, in the Principals thereof, Viz. ≈øo much as is grounded upon Chri≈øtian Tradition, the ∆≤niver≈øal practice of the Church, or the Authority and Definition of General Councils, be (in my per≈øwa≈øion) undoubtedly the True Chri≈øtian Religion, and in all the parts thereof Good and most Acceptable to God, and con≈øequently al≈øo mo≈øt worthy to be embraced, and profe≈ø≈øed by all Chri≈øtians: Yet through the infirmities of Men, and the Vicious corruption of Times, hugely declining in point of Judgment, as well as Manners, from primitive and pri≈øtine integrity, to my extream grief and ≈øcandal, I find it to be here in England, of all others generally ≈øpeaking, an affair, or bu≈øine≈øs, mo≈øt ∆≤nfaithfully and ∆≤nworthily managed by Tho≈øe, who in vertue of their re≈øpective Callings and Offices in the Church of God, have the chief management thereof in their hands.

‚òû The ingenuous Prote≈øtant Reader will not (I hope) be offended, Note. that ≈øuch a Propo≈øition as this is ≈øet in the Front of my Sentiments, it being neither by way of Challenge, nor out of any private confidence, or pre≈øumption ≈øet down, but meerly and ≈øimply as a profe≈ø≈øion of my pre≈øent Belief; which being (as I ≈øaid) ≈øincerely Roman Catholick, I thought it not ∆≤nnece≈ø≈øary to intimate ≈øo much briefly in this place, as well to prevent Scandal-taking by ≈øome, who may be too apt to interpret things to the wor≈øt; as to ≈øhew, that though in the following Propo≈øitions I be to mention with great di≈ølike, many Things of private opinion and practice amongst Roman Catholicks, yet I do it with a clear con≈øcience, and without any (the lea≈øt) prejudice to that Faith, which I hold in common with them, upon the grounds mentioned in the ≈øaid Propo≈øition, Viz. Chri≈øtian Tradition, the Authority of General Councils, &c.

div.head: Propo≈øition II.
div.p: Who are meant by tho≈øe, who have the chief management of Catholick Religion in England, is ≈øufficiently known; therefore I ≈øay in the ≈øecond place, That neither the Con≈øi≈øtory of Rome, nor their principal Corre≈øpondents, (which, as I ≈øaid, are the Je≈øuits, Monks and Friers, with ≈øome few others of the Engli≈øh and Iri≈øh Clergy, pen≈øion'd by procurement and help of the Je≈øuits, &c. and therefore wholly dependent on them) do at all ≈øeriou≈øly de≈øire any general advancement, or liberty of Catholick Religion, nor any General Conver≈øion of the People of this Nation from the Errours of Prote≈øtanti≈øm: But only make u≈øe of that pretence for their reputation ≈øake, and the better to carry on their own private, and more intended De≈øigns; which are Ambition, Honour with Ea≈øe, Emolument, Power, Authority, and the like.
